Award.AwardTitle: Dynamic Exchange and Reactivity in Secondary Organic Aerosol
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project consists of laboratory experiments that will lead to a better understanding of the physical and chemical properties of atmospheric aerosol and the dynamics of exchange between gas-phase and particle phase species. This research is important for making future predictions of aerosol behavior and the influence of atmospheric aerosol on global climate and regional air quality.

The goal of this project is to define the role of particle phase, species diffusivity, and species volatility in the dynamic exchange and reactivity of secondary organic aerosol. Experiments have been designed to address the following objectives: (1) better understand how temperature and relative humidity affect the diffusivity of various organic species; (2) determine how the reactive history, including the volatile organic carbon precursor of the particle, affects the diffusivity of the organic species; and (3) develop structure-function relationships between the diffusivities of organic species and their functional groups/molecular weights.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Atmospheric particles play significant roles in climate, air quality, and human health. This NSF-funded project made significant new scientific findings on the interaction of gas-phase semivolatile organic compounds with organic aerosol particles in the atmosphere. Students in this project learned first-hand from experimental methods, and the data sets proved valuable for case studies in classroom settings to ground student interest in applications as well as excite new students to join and continue in STEM studies. The project findings showed that gas-particle interactions can not only affect the mass concentration of organic particulate matter but also greatly alter important physical properties of atmospheric particles, such as size, optical properties, and surface tension. The gas-particle interactions are governed by multiple parameters, such as the functional groups, molecular weights, and volatility of gas-phase species, as well as the physical liquid or liquid-like state and composition of the particles, along with the interactions between the gas and particle properties. These results advance our understanding of the coupling between physical and chemical interactions that affect the dynamic exchange of molecules between the gas and particle phases. The better understanding leads to more accurate modeling of the role of aerosol particles in climate. The findings relate diffusivity of a medium to gas-phase uptake and as such have further applications in various fields, including material science, biomedical science, and physical chemistry. Improved predictions are possible for the intersection and impacts between atmospheric chemistry and human health, air quality, and climate, and improving models of atmospheric chemistry leads to higher probabilities of desired outcomes and impacts of government policy decisions.
